topics.name: Work Done
topics.description: Work done is the energy transferred when a force moves an object over a distance.

topics.name: Force
topics.description: Force is a push or pull upon an object resulting from its interaction with another object.

topics.name: Energy
topics.description: Energy is the capacity to do work.

topics.name: Power
topics.description: Power is the rate at which work is done.

topics.name: Kinetic Energy
topics.description: Kinetic energy is the energy an object possesses due to its motion.

topics.name: Potential Energy
topics.description: Potential energy is the energy an object possesses due to its position in a force field, typically gravity.

topics.name: Momentum
topics.description: Momentum is the quantity of motion of a moving body, measured as a product of its mass and velocity.

topics.name: Impulse
topics.description: Impulse is the change in momentum of an object when a force is applied over time.

topics.name: Pressure
topics.description: Pressure is the force applied per unit area on the surface of an object.

topics.name: Density
topics.description: Density is the mass of a substance per unit volume.

topics.name: Acceleration
topics.description: Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity of an object.

topics.name: Newton's Second Law of Motion
topics.description: Newton's Second Law states that the force acting on an object is equal to the mass of that object times its acceleration.

topics.name: Gravitational Force
topics.description: Gravitational force is the attractive force between two masses.

additional_info.G_unit: Newton meter squared per kilogram squared (N·m²/kg²)

topics.name: Friction
topics.description: Friction is the force resisting the relative motion of two surfaces in contact.
topics.formula: Friction Force = Coefficient of Friction × Normal Force

topics.name: Torque
topics.description: Torque is a measure of the rotational force applied to an object.
topics.formula: Torque = Force × Lever Arm Distance × sin(θ)

topics.name: Centripetal Force
topics.description: Centripetal force is the force that keeps an object moving in a circular path.

topics.name: Wave Speed
topics.description: Wave speed is the speed at which a wave travels through a medium.

topics.name: Ohm's Law
topics.description: Ohm's Law states that the current through a conductor between two points is directly proportional to the voltage across the two points.

topics.name: Electric Power
topics.description: Electric power is the rate at which electrical energy is transferred by an electric circuit.

topics.name: Hooke's Law
topics.description: Hooke's Law states that the force needed to extend or compress a spring by some distance is proportional to that distance.

topics.name: Thermal Energy
topics.description: Thermal energy is the internal energy of an object due to the kinetic energy of its atoms or molecules.

additional_info.specific_heat_capacity_unit: Joule per kilogram per degree Celsius (J/kg·°C)

topics.name: Angular Momentum
topics.description: Angular momentum is the rotational analog of linear momentum, representing the quantity of rotation of an object.
topics.formula: Angular Momentum = Moment of Inertia × Angular Velocity

topics.name: Thermodynamics - First Law
topics.description: The first law of thermodynamics states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transferred or converted from one form to another.

topics.name: Thermodynamics - Second Law
topics.description: The second law of thermodynamics states that the total entropy of an isolated system can never decrease over time.

topics.name: Electric Field
topics.description: An electric field is a region around a charged particle where a force would be exerted on other charged particles.
topics.unit: Newton per coulomb (N/C) or Volt per meter (V/m)

topics.name: Magnetic Field
topics.description: A magnetic field is a field produced by moving electric charges, which exerts a force on other moving charges.

topics.name: Capacitance
topics.description: Capacitance is the ability of a system to store an electric charge.

topics.name: Inductance
topics.description: Inductance is the property of a conductor by which a change in current in the conductor induces a voltage in both the conductor itself and in any nearby conductors.

topics.name: Snell's Law
topics.description: Snell's Law describes the relationship between the angles of incidence and refraction when a wave passes from one medium to another.

topics.name: Simple Harmonic Motion (SHM)
topics.description: Simple Harmonic Motion is a type of periodic motion where the restoring force is directly proportional to the displacement and acts in the direction opposite to that of displacement.

topics.name: Wave-Particle Duality
topics.description: Wave-particle duality is the concept in quantum mechanics that every particle or quantum entity exhibits both wave and particle properties.

topics.name: Relativity - Time Dilation
topics.description: Time dilation is a difference in the elapsed time measured by two observers, due to a relative velocity between them or a difference in gravitational potential.

topics.name: Relativity - Length Contraction
topics.description: Length contraction is the phenomenon by which the length of an object moving at relativistic speeds is measured to be shorter than its proper length.

topics.name: Photoelectric Effect
topics.description: The photoelectric effect is the emission of electrons or other free carriers when light shines on a material.

topics.name: Doppler Effect
topics.description: The Doppler effect is the change in frequency or wavelength of a wave in relation to an observer moving relative to the wave source.

topics.name: Entropy
topics.description: Entropy is a measure of the randomness or disorder of a system.

topics.name: Quantum Mechanics - Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle
topics.description: The Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle states that it is impossible to simultaneously know the exact position and momentum of a particle.

topics.name: Schrödinger Equation
topics.description: The Schrödinger equation describes how the quantum state of a physical system changes with time.

topics.name: Planck's Law
topics.description: Planck's Law describes the spectral density of electromagnetic radiation emitted by a black body in thermal equilibrium at a given temperature.

topics.name: Relativity - Mass-Energy Equivalence
topics.description: Mass-energy equivalence is the principle stating that mass can be converted into energy, encapsulated by Einstein's famous equation.

topics.name: Blackbody Radiation
topics.description: Blackbody radiation refers to the electromagnetic radiation emitted by a body in thermal equilibrium.

additional_info.stefan_boltzmann_constant_unit: Watt per square meter per Kelvin to the fourth (W/m²·K⁴)

topics.name: Fluid Dynamics - Bernoulli's Principle
topics.description: Bernoulli's Principle states that an increase in the speed of a fluid occurs simultaneously with a decrease in pressure or a decrease in the fluid's potential energy.

topics.name: Gauss's Law
topics.description: Gauss's Law relates the distribution of electric charge to the resulting electric field. It states that the electric flux through a closed surface is proportional to the charge enclosed by the surface.
